unnormalised: ## My EMI Journey: From Worry to Relief
normalised: ## My E-M-I Journey: From Worry to Relief

unnormalised: Getting a loan in India can feel like a rite of passage. Everyone I know has either taken one, is planning to, or is currently drowning in EMIs. I definitely fall into the second category... well, *did*. I wanted to share my experience because navigating the world of loans, especially repayment, can be intimidating, even with all the information online. I needed ₹5,00,000 for my sister's wedding, and saving that up quickly just wasn't an option. So, a personal loan it was!
normalised: Getting a loan in India can feel like a rite of passage. Everyone I know has either taken one, is planning to, or is currently drowning in E-M-Is. I definitely fall into the second category... well, *did*. I wanted to share my experience because navigating the world of loans, especially repayment, can be intimidating, even with all the information online. I needed rupee five hundred thousand for my sister's wedding, and saving that up quickly just wasn't an option. So, a personal loan it was!

unnormalised: The initial rush of having the money was amazing, but the reality of the EMI payments hit hard. I chose a 5-year tenure, and initially, the thought of paying ₹10,623 every month seemed manageable. But life, as it often does, had other plans. Unexpected expenses cropped up like weeds – a sudden repair to my auto-rickshaw (essential for my small business), medical bills for my mom (bless her heart), and even a small, impromptu trip to Goa with friends (regretted that one later!).
normalised: The initial rush of having the money was amazing, but the reality of the E-M-I payments hit hard. I chose a five year tenure, and initially, the thought of paying rupee ten thousand six hundred and twenty three every month seemed manageable. But life, as it often does, had other plans. Unexpected expenses cropped up like weeds – a sudden repair to my auto-rickshaw (essential for my small business), medical bills for my mom (bless her heart), and even a small, impromptu trip to Goa with friends (regretted that one later!).

unnormalised: Around month 18, I started struggling. I missed an EMI payment. The bank, HDFC, was surprisingly understanding, but the late payment charges stung. That's when I realised I needed a proper strategy. I started tracking every rupee I spent. I cut down on unnecessary expenses (goodbye, weekend movie nights!). I even started selling some of my old books and clothes online. Every little bit helped. I was determined to get my finances back on track.
normalised: Around month eighteen, I started struggling. I missed an E-M-I payment. The bank, H-D-F-C, was surprisingly understanding, but the late payment charges stung. That's when I realised I needed a proper strategy. I started tracking every rupee I spent. I cut down on unnecessary expenses (goodbye, weekend movie nights!). I even started selling some of my old books and clothes online. Every little bit helped. I was determined to get my finances back on track.

unnormalised: One thing that was super helpful was talking to a financial advisor. My friend, Rajat, works at ICICI Bank, and he gave me some amazing advice. He suggested prepaying small amounts whenever I had extra cash. Even ₹5,000 here and there would reduce the principal amount and shorten the loan tenure. I also learnt about refinancing, but decided against it since the interest rates were similar to what I was already paying.
normalised: One thing that was super helpful was talking to a financial advisor. My friend, Rajat, works at I-C-I-C-I Bank, and he gave me some amazing advice. He suggested prepaying small amounts whenever I had extra cash. Even rupee five thousand here and there would reduce the principal amount and shorten the loan tenure. I also learnt about refinancing, but decided against it since the interest rates were similar to what I was already paying.

unnormalised: I also discovered the magic of budgeting apps! Apps like Groww and ET Money can track your expenses, set financial goals, and even offer investment suggestions. It's like having a personal accountant in your pocket! They really helped me understand where my money was going and identify areas where I could cut back. For example, my monthly spend on Zomato/Swiggy was averaging ₹2,500. I've managed to cut it down to just ₹500.
normalised: I also discovered the magic of budgeting apps! Apps like Groww and E-T Money can track your expenses, set financial goals, and even offer investment suggestions. It's like having a personal accountant in your pocket! They really helped me understand where my money was going and identify areas where I could cut back. For example, my monthly spend on Zomato slash Swiggy was averaging rupee two thousand five hundred. I've managed to cut it down to just rupee five hundred.

unnormalised: It took discipline and commitment, but I finally managed to prepay a significant chunk of the loan. Doing this slashed the remaining tenure and the overall interest I would pay. I still have about 12 months left, but the finish line is in sight!
normalised: It took discipline and commitment, but I finally managed to prepay a significant chunk of the loan. Doing this slashed the remaining tenure and the overall interest I would pay. I still have about twelve months left, but the finish line is in sight!

unnormalised: So, if you're struggling with loan repayments, remember you're not alone. It’s about making small, consistent changes, seeking advice, and staying focused on your goal. And remember, that feeling of finally being debt-free? It's worth every sacrifice! Good luck, folks!
